Information Page

How AI is used in Different Branches of Healthcare

Pediatrics. Level of AI Usage: Moderate

AI is helping doctors care for children by improving how they diagnose illnesses, manage patient records, and even communicate with families.

  • AI is used in pediatric triage systems to quickly assess symptoms and prioritize care, especially in emergency settings.
  • Doctors use AI to help with documentation and translation, making it easier to treat children from diverse backgrounds.
  • Researchers are also exploring how AI can detect pain in newborns who can't speak, using facial recognition and other signals.

    • Neuroscience. Level of AI Usage: High

    In brain-related healthcare, AI is helping scientists and doctors understand and treat conditions like stroke, Parkinson’s disease, and paralysis.

  • AI-powered tools are being developed to help stroke patients recover at home using virtual reality and brain-computer interfaces.
  • Some researchers are using AI to restore speech in people with paralysis by decoding brain signals.
  • AI is also helping track eye movements in Parkinson’s patients to detect cognitive decline earlier.

    • Cardiology. Level of AI Usage: High

    AI is transforming heart care by helping doctors detect problems earlier and personalize treatments for better outcomes.

  • The American Heart Association funded $10.5 million in research to use AI for improving heart ultrasound scans and CPR techniques.
  • AI can now detect hidden signs of kidney and liver disease during heart scans, which helps prevent complications.
  • Wearable sensors powered by AI are being tested to guide CPR in real time, improving survival chances during cardiac arrest.

    • Oncology (Cancer Care). Level of AI Usage: High

    AI is being used to detect, diagnose, and treat cancer more accurately and efficiently.

  • AI tools are now being integrated into clinical practice to help doctors analyze medical images and genetic data for cancer diagnosis.
  • These tools can predict how a patient might respond to treatment, helping doctors choose the best options.
  • AI also helps researchers find patterns in huge datasets, speeding up cancer research and improving patient care.

    • Radiology. Level of AI Usage: Very High

    Radiology is one of the first areas where AI has made a big impact, helping doctors read scans faster and more accurately.

  • AI systems can detect critical conditions like strokes or blood clots within minutes of a scan being completed.
  • A new framework developed at the University of Miami helps hospitals safely integrate AI into radiology workflows.
  • These systems also reduce radiologist burnout and improve patient outcomes by speeding up diagnosis and treatment.

    • Pathology. Level of AI Usage: Moderate to High

    Pathology involves studying tissues and cells to diagnose diseases. AI is helping pathologists work faster and more precisely.

  • AI tools can analyze blood samples to detect diseases like leukemia in just minutes, which is much faster than traditional methods.
  • The College of American Pathologists is working with the FDA and other groups to ensure AI tools are safe and effective.
  • AI is also being used in education to help train future pathologists and improve how they learn complex topics.


    • AI's Evolution Through Time

    Here’s a simplified overview of how Artificial Intelligence (AI) has evolved in medicine over time, with a focus on three key periods: the 1950s, 1980s, and 2020s. Each section includes a short intro and three mini-paragraphs to help you understand AI’s growing role in medical development. All claims are supported by reliable sources and cited in MLA 9th edition format using inline superscripts.

    1950s: The Birth of AI Concepts in Medicine

    In the 1950s, AI was still a new idea. Computers were just beginning to be used in science, and researchers were exploring how machines could help solve medical problems.

  • The concept of AI was formally introduced at the Dartmouth Summer Research Project in 1956, where scientists imagined machines that could simulate human intelligence.
  • Early medical computing focused on basic tasks like automating patient questionnaires and organizing health data, laying the groundwork for future AI applications.
  • Although AI wasn’t yet practical for medicine, pioneers like Alan Turing and John McCarthy helped shape the vision of intelligent machines that could one day assist doctors.

    • 1980s: AI Begins to Assist Medical Decisions

    By the 1980s, AI had started to be used in real medical settings. Computers were more powerful, and researchers began building systems to help diagnose diseases.

  • Medical AI programs like MYCIN and INTERNIST were developed to assist doctors in diagnosing infections and internal diseases using rule-based systems.
  • These systems used symbolic models of diseases and patient symptoms, which allowed them to make recommendations for treatment, a big step forward from earlier statistical methods.
  • The field of medical informatics emerged, combining computer science with healthcare to improve patient care, education, and research.


    • 2020s: AI Revolutionizes Drug Discovery and Personalized Medicine

    Today, AI is transforming medicine in ways that were once unimaginable. One of the biggest breakthroughs is AlphaFold, an AI system that predicted the structure of nearly every known protein.

  • Today, AI is transforming medicine in ways that were once unimaginable. One of the biggest breakthroughs is AlphaFold, an AI system that predicted the structure of nearly every known protein.
  • Researchers at MIT used AlphaFold’s predictions to explore how antibiotics interact with bacterial proteins, aiming to develop new treatments for drug-resistant infections.
  • At the University of Maryland, scientists combined AlphaFold with physics-based simulations to improve drug design, showing how AI can speed up and personalize medicine.


    • Bias and Privacy in Healthcare & Medicine

    Bias:

    AI is increasingly used in skin cancer detection, particularly for identifying melanoma, basal cell carcinoma (BCC), and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Here's how it works—and why bias can emerge:

    How AI Detects Skin Cancer

    AI systems, especially those based on deep learning, are trained using large datasets of skin lesion images labeled with diagnoses. These systems learn to recognize patterns and features in the images that correlate with different types of skin cancer. Here's a simplified breakdown:

    1. Image Collection: Thousands to millions of dermoscopic or clinical skin images are collected.
    2. Labeling: Each image is labeled (e.g., benign, malignant) by dermatologists.
    3. Training: AI models (like convolutional neural networks) learn to associate visual features with diagnoses.
    4. Prediction: Once trained, the AI can analyze new images and suggest whether a lesion is likely cancerous.

    In clinical settings, AI tools assist dermatologists by flagging suspicious lesions, improving diagnostic accuracy and efficiency.


    Why AI in Skin Cancer Detection Can Be Biased

    Despite its promise, AI in dermatology has shown racial and demographic bias, primarily due to issues in data collection and model design:

    1. Lack of Diversity in Training Data

  • Most datasets (e.g., HAM10000) used to train skin cancer AI models are overwhelmingly composed of images from lighter-skinned individuals.
  • This leads to poor performance when diagnosing lesions on darker skin tones, which can appear differently and are underrepresented in the data.
  • Dermoscopic images (taken with a magnifying device) and clinical photographs are the most common modalities.
  • Some datasets include paired multimodal images (both dermoscopic and clinical), which are more valuable for training robust models.
  • Clinical metadata such as age, skin type, lesion location, and history of melanoma are often included to enhance model performance.
  • Lack of diversity: A major issue is the underrepresentation of darker skin tones. In a review of 21 datasets, only 10 images were of brown skin and 1 of dark brown or black skin.
  • Incomplete metadata: Many datasets lack crucial information like patient ethnicity, skin type, and how images were collected.

    • 2. Misclassification Risks

  • AI models trained on biased datasets are more likely to misclassify malignant lesions as benign in people with darker skin, delaying diagnosis and treatment.
  • This is especially concerning because while melanoma is less common in darker-skinned populations, it often has worse outcomes due to late detection.

    • 3. Dataset Imbalance

  • Publicly available skin image datasets often lack demographic metadata (e.g., race, ethnicity, skin phototype), making it hard to audit or correct for bias.
  • Even when datasets include diverse images, models may still underperform due to contextual differences in lesion presentation across populations.

    • 4. Technical Limitations

  • AI struggles with images that include excessive hair, non-standard lighting, or non-circular lesion shapes, which are more common in real-world settings.

    • Efforts to Reduce Bias

    Some newer models, like SkinWiseNet (SWNet), use techniques like feature fusion—combining insights from multiple diverse datasets—to improve accuracy across skin tones. Others propose frameworks like Predictive Representativity, which focus on fairness in model outcomes rather than just dataset composition .

    AI models for skin cancer detection are often trained on datasets like HAM10000, which contain mostly images of lighter skin tones—about 95% Fitzpatrick types I–III, and only ~5% representing darker skin (types IV–VI). This imbalance causes the models to underperform for darker skin, misclassifying malignant lesions as benign, which can delay diagnosis and treatment. Even though melanoma is less common in darker skin, mortality is 3.75× higher due to late detection.

    The lack of skin tone metadata and poor representation in datasets makes it hard for AI to generalize across diverse populations.

    For fairness, researchers suggest:

  • Using diverse datasets
  • Adopting better skin tone scales like the L’Oréal Color Chart
  • Auditing models with frameworks like Predictive Representativity

    • How bias can impact vulnerable populations:

    AI bias in skin cancer detection can seriously impact vulnerable populations, especially those with darker skin tones. Here are key issues:

  • Delayed or Missed Diagnoses: AI models often misclassify malignant lesions in darker skin as benign, leading to delayed treatment and higher mortality rates.
  • Worse Prognosis: Although melanoma is less common in darker-skinned individuals, they face a 3.75x higher mortality rate due to late detection.
  • Limited Dataset Diversity: Most AI models are trained on images of lighter skin, making them less effective for diagnosing conditions in patients of color.
  • Amplified Bias in Primary Care: AI assistance improves accuracy overall, but primary care physicians—especially those with limited experience treating darker skin—show increased diagnostic bias when using AI tools.
  • Restricted Generalizability: AI models trained on biased datasets fail to perform well in real-world, diverse clinical settings, limiting their usefulness for underserved communities.

    • Privacy:

  • 🔐 Your health info might not be safe – AI needs lots of skin pictures and medical data, which could be stolen or misused if not protected well.
  • ❌ You might not know your data is being used – Sometimes your info is used to train AI without asking you first. There’s a lack of transparency in how your data is being collected and stores too.
  • 🕵️ Even anonymous data can be traced back to you – Removing your name doesn’t always mean your identity is fully hidden.
  • ⚖️ Laws don’t always cover AI use – Rules like HIPAA may not fully protect how AI uses your medical data. Another question is who is liable if AI misdiagnoses a patient? Is it the AI company, the doctor’s office, or both?
